Ken Stanley and I are pleased to annouce our new article, "Evolvability is =
Inevitable: Increasing Evolvability without the Pressure to Adapt," which w=
as published today in PLoS ONE. The paper can be viewed at: 

http://dx.plo=
s.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0062186

The article applies both abstract simul=
ations and neuroevolution to explore a non-adaptive explanation for increas=
ing evolvability in nature. Interestingy, understanding evolvability (the c=
apacity to further evolve) might lead not only to better understanding how =
complex organisms evolve in nature, but may also provide insight into how t=
o design evolutionary algorithms that are better able to evolve complex art=
ifacts.

Most existing theories for evolvability increase depend upon parti=
cular selective scenarios, such as a species surviving through constantly c=
hanging environments. However, the insight in the article is that evolvabil=
ity can instead arise spontaneously without natural selection acting at all=
. The main idea is that if evolvability is heritable, then evolvable organi=
sms separate themselves naturally from less evolvable organisms over time s=
imply by their children becoming increasingly diverse and thereby spreading=
 further through the space of possible phenotypes. That is, the space of ph=
enotypes itself can act like a filter that distinguishes evolvability.

In =
this way, when novel phenotypes appear in the future, they are most likely =
descendents of those that were evolvable in the past. The result is that ev=
olvable species accumulate over time even without selective pressure. This =
idea is supported by a variety of simulations where evolvability increases =
without any pressure for organisms to out-compete each other.

Those famili=
ar with novelty search will notice some conceptual parallels with Ken's and=
 my previous work on searching without objectives. Like novelty search, the=
 proposed non-adaptive hypothesis for evolvability may invite some controve=
rsy because adaptive explanations for evolvability are intuitive and widely=
-held. For example, researchers often worry about what kind of selective pr=
essure will lead to evolvability, even in discussions in this group. One im=
plication of this work could be that such worrying is unwarranted because t=
he best way to get evolvability may sometimes be to stop trying to select f=
or it. In any case, despite any potential controversy, we hope that this al=
ternate perspective leads to constructive discussion and demonstrates the n=
eed to question the assumption that evolvability requires particular select=
ive scenarios for it to increase.

Joel
